title: How lightning happens: Dr Karl's step-by-step guide
text:
(Rob Henderson/ Getty Images) 
It take a unique series of weather factors to create the awesome power of lightning, and when it strikes it comes to earth with 1,000 times more energy than a household electrical system and with more heat than the sun. Dr Karl Kruszelnicki explains. 
Lightning is so impressive that when it happens it stops you in your tracks. Many have asked, "Why don't we capture this awesome power, and use it to power our industries and boil our kettles?" 
Lightning flashes into existence about 1.4 billion times each year across the whole planet. 
This electrical tension between the bottom of the cloud and the ground can be huge—in extreme cases, it can make your hair stand on end. 
One-and-a-half billion lightning bolts sounds like a lot, but only about one quarter of them get to the ground. The rest of the lightning happens either within a single cloud or from one cloud to another. 
We still don't fully understand how a bolt of lightning gets started, but we have some idea. 
The process begins inside a thunderstorm, where the two important ingredients are located. First, there's air moving rapidly upwards, and second, there are freezing temperatures (ranging between 15 and 25 degrees below zero). 
These rather perverse conditions produce three types of water. First, and rather surprisingly, there's some actual liquid water in the shape of small droplets that are super-cooled. 
Second, as you would expect, there are small crystals of hail. Third, and again a bit unexpected, there are quite large blobs of soft hail with the unusual name of "graupel". Graupel is between two and five millimetres across, and occurs when super-cooled water freezes on the outside of, say, a snowflake. 
Thanks to the strong updrafts of wind, the graupel runs into the other two types of water (the small super-cooled droplets and the small ice hail). Via a complicated process, they become positively charged, while the graupel becomes negatively charged. 
The super-cooled water droplets and hail are much smaller and lighter, so the strong up-currents of wind inside the thundercloud carry them upwards. This process makes the top of the thundercloud become positively charged. 
The positive charges repel each other. This is part of the reason that you get the so-called "anvil"—the large flattened area at the top of a thundercloud. 
The third type of water, the graupel, is larger and heavier than the two other types, and either stays where it is in the strong updraft or falls to the bottom of the cloud. 
Either way, the bottom of the cloud becomes negatively charged. This negative charge on the bottom of the cloud induces a positive charge on the ground, a kilometre or more below.

This electrical tension between the bottom of the cloud and the ground can be huge—in extreme cases, it can make your hair stand on end. Eventually, over about a 20,000th of a second, a lightning strike stutters its way towards the ground in a series of steps. Each step is about 45 metres long—a tad smaller than an Olympic swimming pool. 
This downward-going lightning bolt is clearly visible—even though it's travelling at about 200 kilometres a second. It's carrying about 10-100 amps of current. For comparison, 10 amps running a domestic electrical heater will make the power cable a bit warm, while 100 amps is a bit more than your entire house can draw from the electrical grid. 
Now this downstroke—impressive as it is—is just the warmup for the main event. On its way down, the downstroke has blasted a conductive pathway between the bottom of the cloud and the ground. What happens next is the return stroke—which is much more powerful and yet kind of invisible. 
Instead of carrying 10-100 amps of current, it carries 30,000 amps—sometimes as much as 120,000. This stupendous amount of current is enough to create temperatures 10 times hotter than the surface of the Sun—50,000 degrees. This causes the characteristic blue-white colour of a lightning bolt. 
The air is heated almost instantaneously, making it expand explosively, producing a shock wave, which we hear as thunder. 
But it's kind of invisible because it's moving so fast. 
While the downstroke of the lightning strike moves at about 200 kilometres a second, the upward return stroke zips along at 100,000 kilometres a second—about one third of the speed of light. 
All you see with the naked eye is the slower downward strike and a really bright flash of light from the upward return stroke. 
The only way you can "see" the upward movement of the return stroke is if you use a military-industrial-scientific-grade ultra-high-speed camera—otherwise all you see is a flash.
